node.title: He Was a Black Star 60 Years Before Jackie. Now He’s a Hall of Famer.
node.alt: Bud Fowler, center, was a Black baseball star in the 19th century who played organized baseball against white players before the sport established its racist color line.
node.description: Elected by the Hall’s Early Days committee, Bud Fowler was a pioneer who played organized professional baseball against white players as early as 1878.
node.content: ["Bud Fowler was far more than a curiosity.", "A professional player in the late 19th century, Fowler is considered by many to have been the first Black player to compete in organized baseball against white players. But many news media reports on his travels around various professional teams and leagues in those days made it clear that the two-way star, who pitched and played catcher in addition to his exploits as a fleet second baseman, was a player to be reckoned with regardless of his race.", "In 1882, The Times-Picayune in New Orleans noted that Fowler would be playing a game for a local team, the Pickwicks, and referred to him as \u201cthe celebrated colored curve pitcher of Lynn, Mass.\u201d", "When the Lawrence Eagles were playing the Kansas City Novels in 1886, The Evening Tribune in Lawrence, Kan., mentioned that Fowler, \u201cthe phenomenal colored player of Topeka,\u201d would be playing for the Eagles. And when Fowler was reportedly considering playing for a team out of Plattsmouth, Neb., in 1891, The Omaha Daily Bee endorsed the move, saying Fowler was \u201cone of the best men in his position that can be found and would be a good acquisition to the team.\u201d", "Words like \u201cpioneer\u201d and \u201ctrailblazer\u201d are often used to describe Fowler, and on Sunday he added a new title: Hall of Famer. Fowler is part of a six-person class that was elected by a pair of committees asked to review players from baseball\u2019s past. Of the six players, he has the least name recognition, but his exclusion has long been viewed as a mistake by baseball historians.", "While Buck O\u2019Neil, a player and manager for the Kansas City Monarchs, and Minnie Mi\u00f1oso, who played for the New York Cubans at the start of his career, were the first players from the Negro leagues to be elected to the Hall of Fame since 2006 \u2014 and the first to be elected since several Negro leagues were recognized by Major League Baseball last year as having been major leagues \u2014 Fowler\u2019s career predated most of those organized Negro leagues. Much of it came before the white major and minor leagues effectively barred Black players in the late 1880s.", "Fowler helped organize teams and leagues of Black players, including the famed Page Fence Giants in Adrian, Mich., and was known to give scouting reports on Black players to teams looking for new talent. Official statistics are so sparse from his career that it is hard to paint a picture of him as a player, but reports from the time made it clear that he was among the game\u2019s most talented players.", "Despite starring in several leagues that were predominantly white, Fowler encountered racism throughout his career from teammates, club leaders, local communities, hotels and restaurants.", "In 1887 he was playing in the International League, a top minor league that considered itself a rival of the National League, when multiple instances of players refusing to play with or against Black players \u2014 one of which was spearheaded by the Hall of Famer Cap Anson \u2014 resulted in that league formally barring Black players. That vote is seen by many as having established baseball\u2019s racist \u201ccolor line,\u201d which held until Jackie Robinson was signed by the Brooklyn Dodgers and then assigned to the Montreal Royals in 1946.", "The move to bar Black players in 1887 had nothing to do with ability. In the book \u201cOnly the Ball Was White,\u201d the historian Robert Peterson discussed the barred International League players, saying, \u201cFrank Grant, Bud Fowler and George Stovey were unquestionably of major league star caliber.\u201d", "Fowler continued to play organized baseball until at least 1895, and he died in 1913. Most of his later life remains a mystery because he did not keep a diary or other papers to study. His grave in Frankfort, N.Y., went unmarked until the Society for American Baseball Research placed a memorial there in 1987.", "Fowler, who grew up in Cooperstown, N.Y., was honored by his home city in 2013 when it renamed a street \u201cBud Fowler Way.\u201d And now, more than 100 years after his death, Fowler will receive baseball\u2019s highest honor in a field just miles from where he grew up."]
